questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Folliculitis is usually of bacterial nature.
questions.explanation: True. Folliculitis, an inflammation of the hair follicles, is most commonly caused by a bacterial infection, particularly Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Folliculitis doesn't occur in all age groups.
questions.explanation: False. Folliculitis can affect individuals of any age, as it is related to hair follicles which are present throughout life.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Topical antibiotics are usually prescribed for folliculitis.
questions.explanation: False. Mild cases of folliculitis often clear up on their own with proper hygiene. Topical antibiotics are typically reserved for persistent or more severe bacterial cases.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Prurigo nodules are not necessarily follicular based.
questions.explanation: True. Prurigo nodularis is a skin disease characterized by itchy nodules that are not always associated with hair follicles.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Miliaria is an occlusion of eccrine sweat glands.
questions.explanation: True. Miliaria, also known as heat rash or prickly heat, is caused by the blockage of the eccrine sweat ducts, leading to trapped sweat beneath the skin.
